facts.text: Respondents are admittedly the landlords of the premises, No. 24, Ansari Road, Darya Ganj, Delhi.
Appellant claims to have been in occupation of the premises since prior to 1950, at a monthly rent of Rs. 50/-
In 1955, the respondents instituted a suit for eviction of the All India Postal R.M.S. Union, and the appellant was impleaded as a party.
In 1958, respondents applied for amendment of the plaint stating the father of the first respondent let the building to the appellant for residential purposes.
Subordinate Judge refused amendment but permitted withdrawal with liberty to file fresh suit on May 8, 1959.
On February 25, 1960, respondents applied to Rent Controller, Delhi, for eviction of appellant alone, without impleading the Union.
Appellant contended premises let to Union for office-cum-residential purposes, tenancy of Union not terminated; appellant not a tenant.
Eviction petition under s.14(1)(a)(e) of Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958: persistent default in rent; bona fide need for residence as first respondent leaving hospital accommodation.
Appellant denied tenancy, claimed licensee of Union; notice of demand invalid; respondents had suitable accommodation; need not bona fide.
On April 2, 1960, Additional Rent Controller ordered appellant to deposit arrears from August 1, 1958, at Rs.50/- pm and future rent by 15th of following month.
On May 16, 1961, respondents applied under s.15(7) to strike out defence for non-compliance.
Appellant denied default or claimed unintentional due to miscalculation.
On July 26, 1961, Additional Rent Controller struck out defence.
Appeal to Rent Control Tribunal on September 15, 1961, late by one day; dismissed as time-barred and on merits on March 6, 1962.
On July 17, 1961, Additional Rent Controller passed ex-parte ejectment order: prima facie landlord-tenant relation via rent receipts; bona fide need established.
Appeal against ejectment dismissed by Tribunal on March 7, 1962.
Second appeal to Punjab High Court on May 28, 1962, against March 7 order; summarily dismissed May 31, 1962.
No second appeal filed against March 6, 1962, Tribunal order on striking defence.
Special leave granted by Vacation Judge on June 5, 1962.

legal_issues.text: Whether Rent Control authorities had jurisdiction when relationship of landlord and tenant is denied by the alleged tenant.
Whether provisions of s.15(7) of the Act could be applied absent finding of tenancy.
Whether one-day delay in appeal to Tribunal should have been condoned.
Preliminary objection: Appeal incompetent as no second appeal against order striking defence, making it final.

petitioner_arguments.text: Authorities under the Act had no jurisdiction as no landlord-tenant relationship; appellant not tenant but licensee of Union whose tenancy not terminated.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958 lacks express provision to determine landlord-tenant relationship

petitioner_arguments.text: s.15(7) could not apply without finding of tenancy; notice of demand invalid.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.15(7) of Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958

petitioner_arguments.text: Delay of one day in appeal to Tribunal should be condoned; refusal vitiated by erroneous considerations.
Respondents' need not bona fide; had suitable accommodation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.14(1)(e) of Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958

respondent_arguments.text: No second appeal filed against order striking defence (March 6, 1962), making it final; appeal incompetent.
Appellant tenant as per rent receipts; persistent default and bona fide need established.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.14(1)(a)(e), s.15 Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958

court_reasoning.text: Rent Control authorities have jurisdiction to determine landlord-tenant relationship for proceedings under the Act; simple denial does not oust jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act postulates pre-existing relationship but authorities must decide if denied; exclusive jurisdiction within statute.

court_reasoning.text: Order under s.15(1) for deposit assumes tenancy; appellant participated and availed benefits, cannot now deny jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant should have walked out if not tenant; orders for tenant's benefit.

court_reasoning.text: Condonation of one-day delay discretionary; Tribunal considered merits anyway and upheld.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Justification for delay not sufficient; academic as merits upheld.

court_reasoning.text: No second appeal against striking defence order makes it final; inconsistent for appellant to claim benefits then deny tenancy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant took advantages of Act as tenant.

holdings.text: Rent Control authorities have jurisdiction to decide landlord-tenant relationship when denied; denial does not oust jurisdiction.
s.15(7) applicable; appellant deemed to have submitted to jurisdiction by participating.
No interference with discretion on delay condonation.

statutes_cited.name: Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958 (LIX of 1958)
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for eviction on default and bona fide need; deposit of rent; striking defence on non-compliance; assumes jurisdiction over tenancy disputes.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, holding that Rent Control authorities had jurisdiction to proceed despite denial of tenancy, as appellant participated and availed benefits under the Act; lower orders upheld.

key_quotes.text: A simple denial of the relationship either by the alleged landlord or by the alleged tenant would not have the effect of ousting the jurisdiction of the authorities under the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on jurisdiction despite denial of tenancy.

key_quotes.text: If the appellant took his stand upon the plea that he was not a tenant he should have simply denied the relationship and walked out of the proceedings.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It was a little inconsistent on the part of the appellant to have taken all the advantages the Act affords to a tenant and then to turn round and to assert that the Rent Controller had no jurisdiction.
key_quotes.speaker: court
